selected_quotes: My article on why the public dissemination of science matters (Journal of Neuroscience).
6 razones por las que los científicos deberían dedicarse también a la divulgación científica, por David Eagleman
Six (really good) reasons why investing in science communication matters,
many scientists admit concern about criticism from colleagues for forays into the public sphere

citation.abstract: Communicating science to the public takes time away from busy research careers. So why would you do it? I here offer six reasons. First, we owe that understanding to the people who fund our experiments, the taxpaying public. Second, we can leverage our skills as scientists to inspire critical thinking in public and political dialog. Third, researchers are optimally positioned to stem the flow of scientific misinformation in the media. Fourth, we can explain the ways and the means by which science can (and cannot) improve law and social policy. Fifth, it is incumbent upon us to explain what science is and is not: while it is a way of thinking that upgrades our intuitions, it also comes with a deep understanding of (and tolerance for) uncertainty. Finally, we find ourselves in the pleasurable position of being able to share the raw beauty of the world around us-and in the case of neuroscience, the world inside us. I suggest that scientists are optimally stationed to increase their presence in the public sphere: our training positions us to synthesize large bodies of data, weigh the evidence, and communicate with nuance, sincerity and exactitude.
citation.title: Why Public Dissemination of Science Matters: A Manifesto

author.name: NOZAWA, Satoshi
author.description: 科学史・科学論の研究者・大学教員。元天文少年。「新ヒューマニズム」という言葉に出会って科学史の魅力に目覚める。「文化としての科学」をキーワードに科学の形成過程を探究。科学技術政策の過去・現在・未来にも関心。好きなものは、宇宙、書庫、ベルヌーイ、宮崎市定、ピリオド音楽、など。學而不思則罔。思而不學則殆。

author.name: 伊藤憲二
author.description: 科学史家。三浦半島・葉山の地の果てにある総合研究大学院大学というところで「科学と社会」分野を担当していますが、このツイートでの見解は組織の見解とは無関係です。おもに日本における物理学史を研究しています。ＲＴは拡散よりも、あとで参照したり、読むためのものが多く、FAVは当面使いません。もちろん同意や好感を意味しません。
